item.title: Deploy Java Server to Railway
item.description: Steps to take to build the Next.js web app into the Java server and deploy the server to Railway.
item.content:encoded:
Build the Next.js Web Application

The Next.js application file structure is as follows:

root/
├── dist/
├── node_modules/
├── public/
├── src/
├── index.html
├── package.json
└── ...

The Java server folder structure is as follows:

root/
├── HELP.md
├── mvnw
├── mvnw.cmd
├── pom.xml
├── Procfile
├── src
│   ├── main
│   │   ├── java/
│   │   └── resources
│   │       ├── application.properties
│   │       ├── static
│   │       │   ├── assets
│   │       │   │   ├── index-Bf3q5hAT.js
│   │       │   │   ├── index-Dw7cwMGM.css
│   │       │   │   ├── logo-Brnaa614.png
│   │       │   │   └── logo-s-CtewNW4Z.png
│   │       │   └── vite.svg
│   │       └── templates
│   │           └── index.html
│   └── test/
└── target/

Under the web application project root folder run npm run build, the generated static JavaScript and HTML files will be stored under dist.

Next, copy dist/assets under Java server source code directory resources/static, and copy index.html under resources/templates (Don't forget to delete the old ones.)

Build jar File

Inside the root folder (where your mvnw file exists), run ./mvnw clean package -DskipTests. If you are using Eclipse, run maven verify. This will generate a jar file under target directory.

Deploy jar File to Railway

The Procfile is the script for railway. Inside the file, we have

web: java -jar target/your_app_name-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar

Under the root directory, run railway up, then follow the instructions. (Assuming you already installed railway CLI on your machine.)
